Graphical abstract Ni-based catalysts supported on delaminated ITQ-6 zeolite with different Si/Al ratios, 30 and ∞, were tested in the methanation of CO2 and CO. ITQ-6 supports exhibited high surface areas (> 590 m2/g), and the catalysts based on them presented elevated CO2 and CO conversion values, turnover frequencies (TOF), and CH4 selectivity (> 90 %). Comparing the ITQ-6 catalyst and its precursor ferrierite (FER)-based catalyst, H2-chemisorption results confirmed higher metallic dispersion for the former, which resulted in improved H2 uptake and efficient interaction of reaction intermediates via the associative pathway. Combined kinetic studies indicated that their higher available metallic surface contributed to lower apparent activation energies towards CH4 formation, accounting for the higher selectivity values. A 15 wt% Ni-based catalyst supported on ITQ-6 zeolite (Si/Al = 30) exhibited catalytic results (XCO2 = 79 % y SCH4 = 98 %) comparable or even superior to some of the best zeolite-based catalysts reported so far. Keywords ITQ-6 zeolite Ferrierite zeolite CO2 methanation Catalysis Nickel nanoparticles Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Rising levels of CO2 in the atmosphere are a reality, as consistently reported by the IPCC’s (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) last research results [1], and the consequent climate change creates an urgency to develop efficient industrial processes able to reduce greenhouse gas levels to the threshold set by international organizations [2]. CO2 methanation reaction, also known as the Sabatier reaction, emerges as one of the most promising CO2 valorization processes, as it presents several advantages over others once it offers the possibility of using green hydrogen, produced from electrolysis, to reduce CO2 and produce CH4 [3,4]. This gas could be transported by the already existing natural gas pipeline infrastructure or used for the synthesis of other chemicals [5]. The CO2 methanation reaction is exothermic ( Δ H 298 K = - 165 k J m o l - 1 ) and it is thermodynamically favorable even at room temperatures, but its kinetic limitation and the possibility of side reactions forming undesired products, such as C, CO, and CH3OH, are factors that require the use of catalysts for this reaction, which are usually constituted of metallic particles deposited over the surface of inorganic supports [6]. Regarding the metal used in the catalyst’s development, since Paul Sabatier discovered the methanation reaction more than 100 years ago, several catalysts have been developed for carrying it out, with most of them constituted by inorganic supports decorated with metallic particles from groups 8, and 9 and 10, such as Rh, Ru, Ni, Fe, Co, and Pd [7–9]. Nickel emerges as one of the most promising metals for the development of new catalysts, as it is one with the highest conversion to CO2 and selectivity to CH4, while it prevents the occurrence of undesired side reactions [10]. Furthermore, it is significantly less expensive than other metals, making affordable the possibility of scaling up the Ni-based processes to an industrial scale [11]. Regarding the support, it is widely known that it has a strong influence on the CO2 methanation performance, as it alters the metallic phase dispersion and reducibility while playing a critical role in the reaction mechanism, as it activates the CO2 molecules [12]. Some of the main tested supports are CeO2 and MnO2 due to their capability to create oxygen vacancies [13], which are involved in the CO2 methanation mechanism, but also other inorganic oxides, such as TiO2 [14], ZrO2 [15], Al2O3 [16], sepiolite [17], hydrotalcite-like materials [18], mesoporous structured materials (SBA-15, KIT-6, MCM-41) [19], and MOF’s have been taken in consideration [20]. Zeolites are regarded as one of the most promising supports for this reaction due to the very large external surface, which leads to excellent metallic dispersion and increased access of reactant molecules to the support’s active sites, an adjustable ratio of external/microporous surface, and tunable Si/Al ratio, permitting the control of hydrophilicity and CO2 uptake from the material [21–23]. Ferrierite (FER) zeolite crystallizes under the orthorhombic system and presents a bidimensional porous system composed of 10-MR channels (0.43 nm × 0.55 nm) orthogonally intersected by 8-MR (0.38 nm × 0.55 nm), creating a pile of zeolitic layers [24]. Previous results published by Corma et al. allowed the development of a synthetic procedure, which consisted of a swelling step followed by a delamination of one of the FER zeolitic layers, which led to the production, for the first time, of the delaminated version of the FER, the ITQ-6 [25,26]. ITQ-6 is primarily composed of delaminated zeolitic layers, which make up a “house-of-cards-like” structure that exhibits “molecular cups” formed in the sites where the 10-MR channels used to be [27]. This delaminated structure significantly increases the material’s mesoporous volume and surface area, which might reach values higher than 590 m2/g. Due to its unique porous and catalytical properties, ITQ-6 has been described as catalyst support for several chemical reactions, such as alkanes hydroisomerization and hydrocracking [27], organic sulfides oxidation [28], Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [29], dehydrogenation [30], and ethanol steam reforming [31], but so far, there are no reports in the literature using this support for the synthesis of catalysts aimed for CO2 and CO methanation. In this work, Ni-based catalysts over delaminated zeolites (Ni/ITQ-6) have been tested to check their performance towards the CO2 and CO methanation reaction and studied regarding the impact of aluminum content with different techniques, such as XRD, SEM-TEM analyses, H2-TPR, FT-IR, H2-chemisorption and N2 physisorption isotherms determination. With this, the objective of this work was to assess if the ITQ-6 support allows for higher Ni0 dispersion, and if this has an improving effect on the CO2 methanation reaction, increasing conversion and selectivity towards CH4. The incorporation of aluminum into the zeolitic network will also be assessed by FT-IR measurements, regarding its effect on the support’s concentration of surface hydroxyl groups, and the impact on basicity, hydrophilicity, and Ni0 phase dispersion. Finally, after identifying that the aluminum-containing ITQ-6 was the best support among the ones tested, Ni loading on this support was optimized and the catalyst was probed to evaluate the potential prospects of using these delaminated zeolites to prepare efficient catalysts for CH4 production by the Sabatier reaction. 2 Experimental procedure 2.1 Material synthesis 2.1.1 Support synthesis The zeolites used as supports for the catalysts in this work, ferrierite (FER), and its delaminated counterpart, ITQ-6, were synthesized by the hydrothermal procedure as previously described in the literature [32], with two different Si/Al ratios, 30 and ∞, by tuning the amount of Al2O3 added during the initial slurry preparation. In this work, the number indicated between parentheses after the zeolite name indicates its Si/Al ratio. 2.1.2 Preparation of Ni zeolite based-catalysts Two groups of catalysts were synthesized in this work. The first group consisted of low-loading Ni catalysts (5 % wt. Ni) tested at higher space velocity catalytic tests to obtain low CO2 conversions. This was done to conduct reliable kinetic studies at lower temperatures to draw some conclusions about the reaction mechanism, as discussed in the following section regarding the catalytic tests. 5 % wt. content was selected based on our previous results, as this metallic content allows for low conversion values at low temperatures, enabling reliable kinetic studies and discernible results in characterization techniques [17]. Nickel was incorporated into the samples by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) by using Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Aldrich, 98 %) as the metallic precursor. The impregnated solids were left resting for 12 h at room temperature to slowly evaporate the solvent, and finally, all Ni-based catalysts were calcined in a muffle furnace at 450 °C for 2 h and were designated 5Ni/support. In order to activate them for the catalytic tests, the samples were reduced under a 150 mL min−1 H2 flow at 450 °C for 2 h, obtaining the reduced equivalent of the catalysts, which are denominated 5Ni/support_R. After the 5 % wt. Ni catalysts were assessed by catalytic studies, a second group of catalysts was projected to maximize the CO2 conversion. For this, the best support found in the first phase, which happened to be the ITQ-6 (30), was used to prepare higher Ni loading catalysts, and these were tested at lower space velocities to optimize the CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity values. In this phase, three more catalysts supported on ITQ-6 (30) were synthesized also by IWI, 10Ni/ITQ-6 (30), 15Ni/ITQ-6 (30), and 20Ni/ITQ-6 (30). 2.2 Catalysts characterization 2.2.1 Textural properties 100 mg of a solid sample were loaded in a quartz tube of a Micromeritics Quantachrome at ASAP 2020 equipment, degassed at 120 °C, and then analyzed by N2 physisorption at −196 °C. t-plot, BJH, and BET were employed to estimate micropore volume, mesopore volume, and surface area, respectively. 2.2.2 Elemental analysis The amount of residual carbon on the catalysts after the CO2 methanation catalytic tests was estimated with a Carlo Erba 1106 CHN elemental analyzer. 2.2.3 X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) A Philips PANalytical CUBIX diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation ( λ = 1.5418 Å) operating at 40 mA and 45 kV was used to obtain XRD patterns. NiO crystallite size, D NiO , was determined using the Scherrer equation using the (200) plane peak located at 2θ = 43.46°: (1) D NiO = K λ β c o s θ λ is the X-ray wavelength, K is the shape factor, which equals 0.9 and β is the corrected line broadening at half the maximum intensity (FWHM), in radians. 2.2.4 Chemical analysis It was carried out by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). 20–30 mg of the solid samples were digested in an acid solution (HNO3/ HF/ HCl − volumetric ratio: 1:1:3) for 24 h and then diluted with water. Afterward, the solution was injected and analyzed on a Varian 715-ES spectrometer. 2.2.5 Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) 100 mg of the samples were loaded in a quartz reactor of a Micromeritics Autochem 2910 equipment, purged with Ar at 25 °C for 15 min, and then, under a reducing flow (90 % Ar/10 % H2), the reactor was heated to 700 °C, while H2 was measured by a TCD detector. 2.2.6 HAADF-STEM and FESEM microscopy measurements The samples were first reduced under a 150 mL min−1 H2 flow at 450 °C for 2 h, obtaining the reduced catalysts. A JEOL-JEM-2100F microscope operating at 200 kV in both transmission (TEM) and scanning transmission modes (STEM) was used to record HAADF images to check the zeolites delaminated planes and Ni0 particle size distribution. Image J software was used, and 500 particles were counted for each sample, while the normal type of statistical distribution was used to fit the data and calculate the average particle size and standard deviation. In addition, a Zeiss Ultra 55 FESEM microscope at 4 kV was used to analyze the surface morphology of the different catalysts. 2.2.7 Chemisorption analysis 350 mg of a sieved catalyst sample (0.2–0.4 mm) are inserted into a quartz reactor of a Quantachrome Autosorb-1C equipment and reduced (150 mL min−1 H2 flow at 450 °C for 2 h, 10 °C/min), degassed at 30 °C and under vacuum (1.333·10−3 Pa) for 2 h, and exposed to a H2 flow up to saturation to obtain the H2 sorption isotherms. The calculation of metallic nickel surface area, SNi, H2 uptake and molar amount of Ni sites per catalyst gram, N ¯ available , N i , was carried out according to the procedure described by Bartholomew, where the approximations of a H2 monolayer formation are taken into consideration [33]. 2.2.8 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) analyses 100 mg of the sample were treated under vacuum (1.333·10−3 Pa) at 400 °C overnight to get rid of surface water and possible contaminants, and then, the infrared spectra were obtained in a Nicolet iS 10 equipment in the 1200–4000 cm−1 range. 2.2.9 Catalytic tests The CO2 methanation catalytic tests were conducted in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure, at temperatures between 250 °C and 450 °C, as shown in Fig. S1. Two GHSV values were used: 80,000 and 10,000 h−1. The first one was used for the first catalytic tests and kinetic studies, and the second one, to maximize contact time, CO2 conversion, and CH4 selectivity values. In a standard catalytic test, 0.350 g of the catalyst previously sieved (0.2–0.4 mm) was mixed with SiC pellets (0.6–0.8 mm) until reaching a volume of 5 mL to keep the bed volume reactor approximately the same in all experiments. Before introducing reactants into the system, the catalysts were reduced in situ by treating them with a flow of H2 at 450 °C for 2 h (heating ramp = 10 °C min−1). Afterward, the temperature was reduced to 250 °C, and a flow containing the reactants in theoretical stoichiometric proportions (for the CO2 methanation reaction, gas inlet flow: 250 mL min−1, CO2:H2:N2 = 18:72:10; while for the CO methanation reaction, gas inlet flow: 250 mL min−1, CO:H2:N2 = 18:54:28) was introduced into the reactor to start the catalytic tests. Plug flow behavior of the reactor was confirmed, as the reactor dimensions and catalysts particle size follow the boundary conditions equations [34]. A Varian 3800 (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA) gas chromatographer equipped with a HayeSep Q column and two detectors (TCD and FID) quantified the outlet composition of the reactor, as seen in Fig. S1. Quantification was carried out three times for each one of the analyzed temperatures. For CO2 methanation reaction, CO2 conversion ( X C O 2 ), selectivity ( S C H 4 ) towards CH4 and turnover frequency number towards CH4 ( TOF CO 2 ) were calculated using the following expressions: (2) X C O 2 = n ̇ C O 2 , i n - n ̇ C O 2 , o u t n ̇ C O 2 , i n × 100 % (3) S C H 4 = n ̇ C H 4 , o u t n ̇ C H 4 , o u t + n ̇ CO , o u t × 100 % (4) TOF CO 2 = n ̇ C H 4 , o u t 0.350 g × N ¯ available , N i For more information on how the TOF was calculated, the Mathematical Clarification 1 section in the Supplementary Information (SI) document is provided. For CO methanation reaction, CO conversion ( X CO ) and turnover frequency number towards CH4 ( TOF CO ) were calculated using the following expressions: (5) X CO = n ̇ CO , i n - n ̇ CO , o u t n ̇ CO , i n × 100 % (6) TOF CO = n ̇ C H 4 , o u t 0.350 g × N ¯ available , N i where n ̇ C O 2 , n ̇ C H 4 and n ̇ CO are the flows, in mol/h, of CO2, CH4, and CO, respectively, N ¯ available , N i is the molar amount of Ni sites per catalyst gram calculated with the chemisorption technique and the in and out notations refer either to the inlet or outlet reactor flow, respectively. The stability test was carried out at 320 °C for 24 h, with data collection every 24.7 min. This test employed conditions similar to those used for the reaction and with GHSV at 10,000 mL (gcat·h)−1 considering only the reaction reactants, i.e., CO2 and H2. The sample after the stability test is designated (catalyst’s name)_ST, after the initial letters of “Stability Test”. 3 Experimental results and discussion 3.1 Support and catalysts characterization The zeolites ITQ-6 and FER were obtained with different Si/Al ratios (30 and ∞) by preparing the same layered precursor (PREFER) but with different Si/Al ratios. The direct calcination of this precursor led to a multilayer condensation and the formation of the microporous-structured FER zeolites, FER (30), and FER (∞) [32]. For ITQ-6 zeolites, the PREFER precursor is exposed to swelling with CTMA+ for its intercalation in the middle of the interlayer space of the PREFER. Upon sonication in an ultrasound bath, the structure is delaminated, and after ulterior calcination, ITQ-6 zeolites with different Si/Al ratios [FER (30) and FER (∞)] are obtained. ITQ-6 zeolites exhibited lower intensity in the diffraction peaks associated with the planes (h 0 0) compared to their FER counterpart, which points out that there was a loss of crystallinity order along the a-axis [35], suggesting the delamination process took place in this direction (see Fig. S2 in supplementary information). ITQ-6 (30) and ITQ-6 (∞) preserve the (200) and (400) planes diffraction peaks, even though with small intensity, suggesting part of the sample was not delaminated, as it will be further confirmed by t-plot micropore volume calculations. Regarding now the catalysts after Ni incorporation into the supports (FER and ITQ-6), the TG/DTA patterns for all catalysts (Fig. S3) show that after the incorporation of the Ni precursor, at the calcination temperature (450 °C), Ni(NO3)2 is totally decomposed to form a NiO phase. This is evidenced by the XRD patterns, where all calcined samples exhibit the typical peaks associated with the presence of crystalline NiO [36]: 37.40° (111), 43.46° (200), and 63.24° (220) (Fig. 1 and Fig. S4). All calcined catalysts present Ni weight content close to the nominal one, as revealed by ICP results (Table 1 ). The results also confirm that the calcination step did not alter the crystalline structure of zeolite supports, as most of the peaks were preserved in shape and intensity. By measuring the average NiO crystallite size with the Scherrer Equation for the most intense peak attributed to NiO, i.e., the one centered at 43.46°, one notices that for the same Ni content (5 %), it is smaller over the ITQ-6-type catalysts (Table 1). For the ITQ samples with higher Ni content (10 %, 15 %, and 20 %), the higher the Ni loading, the more intense and narrower the NiO peaks become due to the presence of larger NiO crystallites, which is reflected in the average NiO crystallite size trend (Table 1). After the samples were reduced, the peaks arising from the NiO phase disappeared and gave rise instead to the peaks corresponding to the presence of Ni0 particles found at 2θ° = 44.50° (111) and 51.85° (200) (Fig. S5). Furthermore, in the higher Ni loading samples, it is even possible to see the peak located at 2θ° = 76.38° (220) (Fig. S4). With this data, it was possible to calculate the average Ni0 crystallite size (Table 1), which followed the same trend observed for the NiO crystallite size. Reduced catalysts based on Si/Al = 30 supports do not exhibit peaks associated to the presence of NiAl2O4 phase (JCPDS 10–0339), as the formation of these aluminate phases occurs at higher temperatures (>900 °C) for stabilization of the spinel structure, confirming that NiO is exclusively reduced to Ni0 [37]. From HAADF-STEM dark field images of the reduced catalysts (Fig. 2 ) and TEM images shown in Fig. S6, 500 particles were measured, and the Ni0 particle size distributions (Fig. 3 ) confirm the trend observed for the crystallite size obtained from the Scherrer Equation (Table 1). The values observed by HAADF-STEM are higher than those observed by XRD because they pertain to the measurement of observable particles, while XRD measurements determine the average sizes of Ni0 crystallites, which are crystalline domains contained within the actual Ni particles, seen in TEM. SEM images (Fig. 4 ) reveal that for ITQ-6 catalysts, some of the delaminated layers are 50–100 nm thick, suggesting that these layers are composed of aluminosilicate multilayers not completely delaminated [38], which partly preserves the crystallographic order along the a-axis and accounts for the partial preservation of the (200) and (400) planes diffraction peaks (Fig. S2). The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms for the FER and ITQ-6-based catalysts (Fig. 5 ) and their textural properties (Table 2 ) reveal that the isotherms of 5Ni/FER (∞) and 5Ni/FER (30) are type I, which is characteristic of microporous materials [39]. This profile is typical for materials whose pore sizes are not much larger than the kinetic molecular diameter of the adsorbate. This is precisely the case for the FER zeolite, whose channels 10 MR (0.43 nm × 0.55 nm) and 8 MR (0.38 nm × 0.55 nm) are just a little bit larger than the kinetic molecular diameter of N2 (0.364 nm) [24]. Under these conditions, only one adsorbate layer is formed, reaching a plateau level of adsorbate for low P/Po values [40]. Adsorption isotherms for the 5Ni/ITQ-6 (∞) and 5Ni/ITQ-6 (30) catalysts, on the other hand, are type IV, characteristic of mesoporous materials, with an H3 hysteresis. This profile has been previously attributed to mesoporous materials with a wide distribution of mesopore sizes, as no plateau is reached up to higher P/Po values. This is the case for the ITQ-6 catalysts and their “house of cards” structure, which comprises mesopores formed by the random layer piling after the delamination process. Micropore surface area of the FER-type zeolites significantly drops with reductions of over 60 % when converted to ITQ-6-type zeolites, while the external surface increases due to the formation of a “house-of-cards”-type structure. The remaining micropore surface area in ITQ-6 is accounted for incomplete delamination [41], preserving aluminosilicate multilayers that maintain the 10MR channel structure, as seen in SEM images in Fig. 4. A higher delamination extension is observed for the Si/Al = 30 zeolites, for which the increase in the total BET surface area is higher than that observed for the Si/Al = ∞. This had already been suggested by the observation of the intensity of the remaining (200) plane peak in the XRD results when ITQ-6 (30) and ITQ-6 (∞) were compared with each other and was further confirmed by adsorption results. Nickel-based catalysts present lower SBET values than their corresponding bare supports, which is explained by two simultaneous phenomena: first, and on a smaller scale, due to a dilution effect, which has already been reported in previous results of our research group [42] and which takes place due to the deposition of a low surface area phase (NiO) over a higher surface area one (zeolite), decreasing the overall surface area per unit of mass. And secondly, on a more extended scale, the partial obstruction of the micro and mesopores by the NiO particles, leading to a decrease of the micro and mesopore volume (Table 2 ). H2-chemisorption results (Table 3 ) reveal that the same trend is followed in the reduced version of these catalysts, in which the average Ni0 particle size is smaller in the ITQ-6-based catalysts. However, the values are different than the ones measured by XRD or TEM, as they are measured in an indirect way. H2-chemisorption employs H2 molecules as a probe to analyze the Ni0 particles surface area, as determined in the classic study conducted by Bartholomew et al [33], and from this data, the Ni0 particle size is determined. The nickel active metallic surface area is 25 % higher for the 5Ni/ITQ-6 (∞) when compared to the 5Ni/FER (∞) and 31 % higher for the 5Ni/ITQ-6 (30) when compared to the 5Ni/FER (30), which goes hand in hand with the observation of reduction of Ni crystallite size in the same sequence. HAADF-STEM images (Fig. 2) and the size distribution diagrams obtained from these images in Fig. 3 reveal that, on the ITQ-6 supports, the average Ni0 particle size is lower than in non-delaminated counterparts. These measurements confirm the chemisorption results and reveal that in ITQ-6-based catalysts, the distribution of Ni0 particle size is narrower, which is attributed to the higher support surface area, as seen in Fig. 3. Regarding the Al addition, Al-containing catalysts also present, in general, a narrower distribution of the Ni0 particles in comparison with the Al-free catalysts, which is accounted for the presence of zeolitic OH groups, as detected by IR measurements, as it will still be discussed. These anchoring hydroxyl groups allow better dispersion of Ni precursors, as they interact with the nickel precursors during the preparation step and enhance their dispersion [43]. H2-TPR results show peaks at different temperatures for all catalysts because the outcome profile is the overlap of three different profiles related to distinct reduction events for NiO particles (Fig. 6 ). Peaks at lower temperatures regions (α region) refer to the reduction of bulk NiO, which present lower interaction with the support, while the ones at higher temperatures (β and γ regions) refer to the reduction of NiO that hold stronger interaction with the support [44,45]. On the other hand, it is important to highlight that the reduction of Ni2+ as charge compensating cation would not take place since reduction peaks above 630 °C are not detected [44]. For a given nickel loading for a series of catalysts and the same reduction conditions, the amount of available Ni0 sites in the catalysts after reduction will rely on two factors, the reduction extension of the NiO phase and the resulting metallic dispersion, with these two factors being dependent of the strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) between the zeolite support and the nickel phase [46]. The results also reveal that the H2-TPR profile is not strictly correlated with the Ni0 particle size distribution, as it informs about the temperatures in which the NiO phase is reduced, depending on its interaction with the support. The Ni0 particle size, on the other hand, is conditioned by other factors, such as the reduction temperature, time of reduction and the sintering extension, as Ni0 phase reduced below the activation temperature (450 °C) undergoes sintering, which leads to Ni0 particles with different size. By integrating the area below the curve in the H2-TPR results up to the chosen temperature used for the activation by reduction of the catalysts (450 °C), the reduction extension degree is calculated for each catalyst. The higher reducibility at lower temperatures seen in FER-based catalysts is attributed to the bigger NiO crystallites, making most of the Ni species present in the bulk phase, with weaker interactions with the surface and most of the reduction events falling off in the α and β regions, as seen in Fig. 6. Meanwhile, in ITQ-6 catalysts, smaller NiO crystallites are formed, which exhibit stronger interactions with the Si and Al species on the zeolites’ surface, making them harder to reduce and falling off on the β and γ regions of the H2-TPR profiles. This is seen in Fig. 6 in the γ region peaks centered at 460 °C for the 5Ni/ITQ-6 (∞) and one centered at 490 °C for the 5Ni/ITQ-6 (30). Regarding the effect of Ni loading, as the nickel content increases, there is a clear shift of the main peak towards lower temperature values, as observed with the peak at 418 °C for 10Ni/ITQ-6 (30) and 398 °C for 15Ni/ITQ-6 (30) (Fig. S7). This is attributed to the fact that as the Ni content increases, the average size of NiO crystallites also increases, resulting in a higher proportion in the bulk phase, whose reduction is attributed to the aforementioned temperatures. The increase in Ni content also leads to the appearance of new peaks, which is consistent with previously reported results in the literature [47]. This is attributed to the fact that a higher amount of metal leads to greater heterogeneity in NiO particle sizes, which is reflected in the appearance of reduction events at different temperatures. Costa-Serra had already previously described that higher surface area zeolites are supports that lead to better dispersion and smaller nickel oxide particles over the surface [42], and this is confirmed over the delaminated zeolites in this study. Achieving higher dispersion of Ni particles over inorganic supports is related not only to the higher external surface area, but also to other properties, such as hydrophilicity, basicity, and concentration of surface hydroxyl groups, as previously described by other authors [48–50]. IR spectra from these catalysts exhibit three types of hydroxyl groups located in different zeolitic sites, depending on the presence or absence of Al ions inside the network (Fig. S8). IR spectra results (Fig. 7 ) reveal that the nickel impregnation did not significantly modify the profile of hydroxyl groups vibrations, as support and catalyst spectra are practically the same, which is expected, as low nickel loading was employed for all catalysts. Si/Al = ∞ catalysts only exhibit peaks associated with Si-OH hydroxyl groups, typical of Al-free zeolitic supports, found at 3741 cm−1 (Fig. 7). On the other hand, Si/Al = 30 catalysts present a higher concentration of surface OH groups due to the presence of not only SiOH, but also AlOH and Si(OH)Al groups. The vibration of these surface hydroxyl groups is located at lower wavenumbers, centered at 3640 and 3598 cm−1, respectively, as previously described in the literature [51]. In FER zeolites, due to their microporous structure, most of their hydroxyl groups are located within them, however the FT-IR results reveal that the delaminated support, ITQ-6, exhibits a higher concentration of SiOH groups. These groups are obtained by the cleavage of SiOSi dangling bonds during the delamination step treatment with NaOH, which, when split apart give rise to -terminal OH groups as previously reported by Chica et al. [27]. The higher concentration of OH groups on the surface of delaminated and Al-containing zeolites favors the interaction between the support and nickel, which accounts for the higher Ni0 dispersion in catalysts supported on Si/Al = 30 zeolites in comparison with the Si/Al = ∞ ones (Table 3). This is accounted for the fact that by using the impregnation technique, the deposition of the metallic phase relies first on electrostatic interaction between the precursor and the support surface, followed by its subsequent calcination. This way, previous results from the literature reveal that an increase in the concentration of these surface OH groups leads to catalysts with more disperse metallic phase [52,53], which is in consonance with the trend observed for the catalysts in this study. 3.2 Catalytic results discussion CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity for all the 5 % wt. Ni catalysts are presented in Fig. 8 a and b, respectively. As it can be seen, the catalysts based on delaminated zeolite (ITQ-6) show higher CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity values than their counterpart based on FER zeolite. As previously discussed over the XRD and H2-chemisorption results, the delaminated and Al-containing catalysts present smaller Ni crystallite sizes and, as a consequence, larger metallic surface area (Table 3). This sequence aligns with the one observed for CO2 conversion at 450 °C: 5Ni/ITQ-6 (30) > (5Ni/ITQ-6 (∞) > 5Ni/FER (30) > 5Ni/FER (∞) (Fig. 8). 3.2.1 Reaction mechanism To provide insight into the mechanism taking place for these catalysts, kinetic studies were conducted to calculate the TOF values for the CO2 methanation reaction (Table S1). Furthermore, as CO might be an intermediate in the reaction mechanism, catalytic tests and kinetic studies were also carried out for the CO methanation reaction and the results are summarized in Fig. S9 and Table S2. With these TOF values, the Arrhenius plots were performed to calculate the apparent activation energy for the CO2 ( E a , C O 2 ∗ ) and CO methanation reactions ( E a , C O ∗ ) (Fig. 9 ). This will be further used in the mechanism discussion to account for the difference in CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity found across the catalysts supported on different zeolitic supports. These apparent activation energy results are displayed in Table 4 . Taking into account in-situ/operando results and DFT studies available in the literature [55–57], two main mechanistic pathways have been proposed for the CO2 methanation reaction and presented in Fig. 10 : (a) Associative pathway, by which CO2 is first adsorbed, forming intermediate species, such as formates or bicarbonates that are, in the sequence, hydrogenated by adsorbed hydrogen atoms leading to CH4 formation. (b) Dissociative pathway, by which CO2, after adsorption, undergoes dissociation to carbonyl (COads), which is then hydrogenated. Despite the apparent stoichiometric simplicity of the reaction, there are still uncertainties regarding the nature and role of intermediate surface species in the formation of methane. Wu et al. determined from DRIFTS results that over siliceous supports, such as zeolites, the key intermediate to the formation of methane might either be HCOO species or CO, depending on the type of support, basicity, porous structure and experimental conditions, such as temperature and pressure [58]. As seen in Table 4 and Fig. 9, for ITQ-6-based catalysts, E a , C O 2 ∗ < E a , C O ∗ , while for the FER-based catalysts, the opposite trend is observed, E a , C O 2 ∗ > E a , C O ∗ suggesting different mechanisms are taking place in both systems. In the ITQ-6 catalysts, the fact that E a , C O 2 ∗ < E a , C O ∗ explains the low CO selectivity of these catalysts, as the formation of methane via the associative mechanism takes place without relevant formation of C(ads) as an intermediate. Among all the possible reactions, Schmider et al reported that the disassociation steps, from CO2(ads) to CO(ads), and CO(ads) to C(ads), in the dissociative mechanism, are the ones with the highest activation energy, which makes this process a rate-determining step for the dissociative mechanism, favoring instead the associative mechanism [59], as seen in Fig. 10. The higher selectivity to CH4 for the ITQ-6-based catalysts (Fig. 8b) points out that the smaller average Ni0 particles size in comparison with the FER-based catalysts favor the associative mechanism and the formation of intermediate species that are hydrogenated over the metallic surface. The presence of surface OH groups on ITQ-6 catalysts, as detected by IR spectroscopy (Fig. 10), provides further evidence for the lower E a , C O 2 ∗ as these zeolitic surface hydroxyl groups take a role in the adsorption of CO2 molecules on the ITQ-6 surface, and the carbonated intermediates could be reduced by hydrogen species to CH4, as previously reported for the CO2 methanation reaction by Huang et al. [60]. Westermann et al., working on catalysts based on USY zeolite, reported that with the absence of the basic moieties to interact with the CO2 molecules, no carbonate species are formed as intermediates, with most of the conversion taking place through formate dissociation to CO over Ni particles, significantly decreasing total CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity [61], which corroborates the results found in this work. Whilein the FER-based catalysts, E a , C O 2 ∗ > E a , C O ∗ , which is accounted for the presence of larger metallic particles, which leads to a decrease in H2 uptake, as confirmed by the chemisorption results, leading to a less efficient interaction of the H-derived species and the carbon intermediates formed from CO2. 3.2.2 Effect of the delamination of the support In all the catalytic tests, elemental analysis of the spent catalysts revealed there was no significant carbon formation, and the mass balance between inlet and outlet flows was around 100 %. ,For this reason, one can assume there is no significant occurrence of other undesired reactions, such as the Boudouard reaction ( 2 C O → C + C O 2 ), CH4 cracking ( C H 4 → 2 H 2 + C ), and CO reduction ( CO + H 2 → C + H 2 O ), which would lead to coke formation. For the CO2 methanation reaction, ITQ-6-based catalysts exhibit higher CO2 (Fig. 8a), and higher TOF values than their FER-based counterparts (Tables S1 and S2). The first apparent reason for this is that ITQ-6-based catalysts present higher H2 uptake over the metallic surface than the FER-based catalysts, as shown by the H2-chemisorption, which is a consequence of higher metallic dispersion and metallic surface area. H2 uptake from the Ni particles is an important step in the mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation in the associative mechanism, as higher availability of H2 over the metallic particles allows a higher combination with CO2 molecules. The second reason is the higher peripheral zone between the metallic phase and the zeolite surface over the ITQ-6-based catalysts as a consequence of smaller Ni0 particles. As previously discussed in the last section, over ITQ-6-based catalysts, the reaction seems to proceed via the associative mechanism, and part of the CH4 can be formed by the interaction of the carbonated species on the zeolite surface and hydrogen atoms carried out by spillover. This way, in ITQ-6 catalysts, a smaller distance between the hydrogen atoms over the Ni atoms and the CO2 adsorbed on the zeolite surface enhances the interaction between both species. Gao et al., in a study about CO methanation over Ni/α-Al2O3 catalysts, concluded there is an optimum range in size for the Ni nanoparticles to increase the hydrogenation of CO towards CH4 [62]. Too small particles, smaller than 8 nm, presented lower H2 coverage, which decreased CO2 conversion and increased coke formation due to side reactions. At the other point of the size range, too large particles, larger than 20 nm, did not favor the interaction of carbon and hydrogen species, leading to a decrease in conversion. The catalysts with middle-sized particles were the ones that concerted both effects and presented higher conversions and selectivity towards CH4. In another study, Varvoutis et al., concluded that for a series of Ni-CeO2 catalysts, the optimum Ni0 size for CO2 methanation was around 18–20 nm [63]. Smaller particles led to a decrease in the peripheral zone between the support and step/edge and kink/corner Ni0 sites, known to be the active sites for activating CO2 molecules in the reaction mechanism. Larger particles, on the other hand, decreased the step/edge and kink/corner and favored the formation of terrace sites, which are inactive for the activation of molecules. The Ni0 particle size distribution in the catalysts (Fig. 3) reveals that most Ni0 particles in the ITQ-6 catalysts are found between the 8–16 nm range, while in the FER-based ones, larger particles are found, mostly in the 17–30 nm. This confirms that most Ni0 particles over the delaminated supports fall in the middle-size range, accounting for their higher CO2 conversion and selectivity. Regarding selectivity towards CH4, it was found to be very dependent on the kind of support employed. First of all, for all supports, the selectivity towards CH4 decreased when the temperature was increased. With the increase in temperature, the endothermic reverse water–gas shift reaction (RWGS) (Equation (7) is favored in relation to the exothermic CO2 methanation (Equation (8), which accounts for the observed drop in CH4 selectivity for all catalysts. (7) C O 2 + H 2 ⇌ C O + H 2 O Δ H 298 K = + 41 k J / m o l (8) C O 2 + 4 H 2 ⇌ C H 4 + 2 H 2 O Δ H 298 K = - 165 k J / m o l In the ITQ-6-based catalysts, where smaller Ni0 crystallites were found, the main product of the reaction was CH4, with selectivity towards CH4 of over 90 % over the whole range of studied temperatures, even for low CO2 conversion values at lower temperatures (Fig. 8b). Meanwhile, for the FER-based catalysts, which present larger Ni0 crystallites, the selectivity towards CH4 did not surpass 70 % at its highest values at 250 °C and significantly dropped to values as low as 40 % at 450 °C. The higher selectivity towards CH4 on ITQ-6 catalysts is a consequence of the lower E a , C O 2 ∗ in these systems, as previously discussed in the last section, which is associated with the presence of smaller Ni0 particles. Fig. 11 summarizes this discussion by showing that, over the range of average Ni crystallites analyzed, the higher the average Ni0 crystallite size, the higher the E a , C O 2 ∗ value. 3.2.3 Effect of aluminum addition into the zeolite framework Regarding the effect of aluminum addition on the catalytic performance, Bacariza et al. remark that higher Si/Al ratios lead to higher hydrophobicity, which favors the removal of the water molecules after their formation [21], which is a fundamental step so that the succession of hydrogenation steps might take place towards CH4 formation. Contrastingly, a higher Si/Al ratio leads to lower interaction with the solvent during the catalyst preparation step by impregnation due to a lower concentration of surface hydroxyl groups, which leads to lower metallic dispersion catalysts [43]. At the same time, the lower concentration of OH groups affects the material basicity, as these groups act as intermediate basicity sites, which might participate in the CO2 sorption, as previously discussed. Given these three opposite trends concerning the Si/Al ratio, Bacariza et al. report that a delicate balance of the best Si/Al ratio at intermediate values needs to be found for a compromise toward the best performance for the CO2 methanation reaction [21]. In their study, Y zeolites were used as support for Ni-based catalysts, and they reported that the zeolites with Si/Al ratios as low as 3 performed worse than equivalent support with Si/Al = 38, which was attributed to the higher hydrophobicity of the latter, favoring the water removal from the reaction site and the formation of methane. On the other extreme of high Si/Al ratios, Xu et al. employed Ni catalysts supported over low basicity MFI zeolite supports (Si/Al = ∞) and concluded that the absence of basic sites significantly increased the E a , C O 2 ∗ for the methanation reaction, due to the lack of interaction between basic sites and CO2, as confirmed by TPD results [64]. When the system basicity was increased, conversion and CH4 selectivity were significantly increased. Outside of the zeolite field as supports, but still regarding the impact of the presence of basic sites at the support surface, Pan et al. evidenced the role of basicity by comparing the catalytically performance between Ni/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 and Ni/γ-Al2O3 and highlighting that the only difference between them is the strength of hydroxyl and CO2 interactions [65]. While the adsorption of CO2 over the medium basic sites of Ni/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 led to the formation of monodentate carbonates species and eventual CH4 formation, the CO2 molecules adsorbed on the stronger sites found in Ni/γ-Al2O3 did not take part in the reaction, even though they were detected by in-situ DRIFTS. In the specific case of this work, the catalysts supported on Si/Al = 30 zeolites exhibited higher metallic dispersion, which was attributed to the higher hydrophilicity and consequent interaction between the support and the nickel precursors during the preparation step. This led to a higher proportion of nickel crystallites between 10–15 nm, known to be the most active for the methanation reaction. In addition to that, SiAl = 30 zeolites exhibited higher TOF values over the whole range of analyzed temperatures, and lower E a , C O 2 ∗ , as seen in Tables S1 and S2 and 4 Higher catalytic activity on the catalysts based on the SiAl = 30 zeolites compared to their aluminum-free counterparts is rationalized by the favoring effect proportioned by the higher concentration of OH groups, which is achieved by the inclusion of Al inside the zeolite framework and has a consequence on increasing the CO2 uptake. The carbonated intermediates can take part and interact with adsorbed hydrogen atoms, eventually culminating in the formation of hydrogenated intermediates at a lower activation energy cost (Table 4). The mechanism is even more favored when Si(OH)Al groups are present on the catalyst’s surface, such as the ones found in ITQ-6 (30) support, which accounts for the fact that 5Ni/ITQ-6 (30) is the catalyst with higher CO2 conversion and TOF values among the 5 % wt. catalysts. 3.2.4 Effect of nickel content in the catalytic performance Once the ITQ-6 (30) zeolite was identified as the best support for the CO2 methanation reaction, a series of tests was conducted with the 5Ni/ITQ-6 (30) at a lower space velocity (GHSV = 10,000 h−1) than in the first catalytic assessment tests. This was carried out to increase the contact time with the active phase and maximize CO2 conversion [66]. Furthermore, a series of higher loading catalysts on ITQ-6 (30), 10Ni/ITQ-6 (30), 15Ni/ITQ-6 (30), and 20/ITQ-6 (30) were tested for the CO2 methanation reaction by employing the 10,000 h−1 space velocity (Fig. 12 ). The results show that the higher the metallic content, the higher the CO2 conversion values up to a plateau level, with the 15 % wt. Ni catalyst presenting the optimal metallic content. This might be rationalized by the higher H2 uptake, as determined by chemisorption studies (Table 3), and the effect of the availability of these active sites on the reaction mechanism, as discussed in Section 3.2.2. As some of the reaction mechanism takes place at the peripheral zone, there is a limit level of Ni0 active sites that actually participate in the reaction mechanism as previously described by Quindimil et al. for a series of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts [67], and for this, there is barely difference between the 15 % wt. and the 20 % wt. catalysts, as the saturation threshold had already been reached. Regarding the CH4 selectivity, the higher the metallic content, the higher the selectivity, with the higher loading catalysts reaching > 99 % selectivity values at temperatures as low as 350 °C. (Fig. 12). This is attributed to the fact that on higher-loading catalysts, the Ni particle sizes are larger, and, as a consequence, the available metallic surface area is also larger, as confirmed by XRD and chemisorption results. This way, following the associative mechanism previously detected by the kinetic studies, more hydrogen is directly available to fully hydrogenate the carbonated intermediates to CH4, increasing the selectivity values, which is in consonance with other studies published by our research group and other researchers [17,68,69]. Finally, to reach a conclusion about the possibility of employing ITQ-6 (30) catalysts for the CO2 methanation reaction at a larger scale, the results from this study were compared to other results already published in the literature regarding zeolite-based catalysts in Table 5 . It is necessary to consider that, even though the experimental conditions in each study are different, it is possible to individually compare them by focusing on a few experimental aspects. The 15Ni/ITQ-6 (30) catalyst presented higher CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity values than the ones reported by Bacariza et al. [21,70], which carried out a work on Ni-based catalysts supported on 3D zeolites for CO2 methanation. The 15 % wt. Ni catalyst in this work also exhibited higher CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity than other types of zeolite-based catalysts, such as the one reported by Goodarzi et al., which consisted of cage-confined Ni particles inside the 1-silicalite structure [71]. It also displayed higher conversion and selectivity values than some zeolite-based catalysts, in which promoters had been added, such as a Ce-USY reported by Graça [72] and a La-BEA one reported by Quindimil et al. [73]. Indubitably, as previously mentioned, it is necessary to critically take into account the diversity of experimental aspects when this type of literature-oriented comparison is carried out, such as the metallic loading, reduction temperature, and duration, which affect metallic surface area availability, GHSV, contact time and other experimental factors. Nevertheless, the experimental results exhibited by the ITQ-6 (30) catalysts, particularly 15Ni/ITQ-6 (30), place them among the best zeolite-based catalysts reported for the moment, with much potential for an efficient CO2 methanation implementation. The 15Ni/ITQ-6 catalyst was also submitted to a 24-hour-long stability test at 320 °C. This temperature was chosen because CO2 conversion is far from equilibrium and the analysis would be sensitive to the catalyst’s deactivation. The results reveal that CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity are kept relatively constant throughout the analysis with some minor reduction from the initial CO2 conversion at 50.2 % until reaching a stable level at 49.8 % at the end of the test (Fig. 13 ). H2-chemisorption results of the sample after the stability test, 15Ni/ITQ-6_ST, reveal that there is a decrease in the metallic surface area and an increase in average Ni0 particle size (DNi = 19 nm in 15Ni/ITQ-6 (30)_R, and DNi = 21 nm in 15Ni/ITQ-6 (30)_ST) (Table 3). This can be attributed to some sintering of the Ni0 phase taking place to a limited extension, which is rationalized by the large surface area of the ITQ-6 support that ensures good dispersion of the metallic phase. Elemental analysis of 15Ni/ITQ-6_ST reveals that no carbon is formed to a significant extent, confirming that coke is not formed to a significant extension after the test. 4 Conclusions Catalysts based on Ni supported on ITQ-6 and FER zeolites have been prepared and studied in the CO2 and CO methanation reaction. N2 adsorption results showed that the delamination process increases the zeolite total surface area while the microporous surface area drastically decreased, indicating a successful dissociation of the zeolitic aluminosilicate layers of the FER zeolite, which was confirmed by microscopy analyses. XRD results confirmed that a higher delamination extent was achieved for the Si/Al = 30 zeolite due to the presence of aluminum in the solid network and that the employed impregnation techniques deposited Ni0 nanoparticles in the 8–20 nm crystallite size range. Catalytic results for CO2 methanation reaction showed that ITQ-6-based catalysts presented higher CO2 conversion and TOF values, which has been attributed to the better dispersion of metallic Ni particles and confirmed by the particle size distribution determination with TEM images. As confirmed by chemisorption results, their smaller size led to higher H2 uptake on the metallic phase, which, according to the associative mechanistic pathway taken by the reaction, favors the interaction between the reactants. ITQ-6-based catalysts also exhibited higher selectivity values towards CH4 (>90 %) than the ones shown by the FER-based catalysts, which did not surpass 70 %. This has been rationalized by the experimentally determined apparent activation energies, which revealed that, in ITQ-6-based systems, the apparent activation energy for CH4 methanation was lower than that observed for CO methanation. Based on a computational study already published in the literature [59], we then proposed a mechanistic pathway for these systems by which the associative mechanism is favored in the ITQ-6-based catalysts due to the higher Ni0 available surface area, which leads to a higher H2 uptake, favoring the complete reduction of carbon intermediates. Meanwhile, in the FER-based catalysts, lower metallic dispersions are found and, as a consequence, lower H2 uptakes, which leads to partial reduction of CO2 to CO and accounting for the lower selectivity to CH4. Regarding the impact of the addition of Al into the zeolitic network, the Si/Al = 30 catalysts exhibited higher CO2 conversion and TOF values than the pure Si ones, which was attributed to their higher uptake of CO2 on the metal-support interface, as a consequence of their higher basicity, due to the presence of Si(OH)Al groups. Finally, after ITQ-6 (30) was identified to be the best support for the CO2 methanation reaction, higher metallic loading catalysts were also catalytically assessed, and the 15 wt% one presented optimum results (high activity, selectivity and stability after 24 h of reaction time), which were comparable or even superior to some of the best zeolite-based catalysts reported in the literature. In summary, the nature of the support was confirmed to be of paramount importance in developing promising catalysts for the CO2 methanation reaction and the effect of delamination as positive to improve metallic dispersion of Ni0 species and metal-support interaction in the reaction mechanism. This opens a wide window of prospects to explore the use of delaminated zeolites as support for developing new catalysts for CO2 methanation reaction or, furthermore, for industrial-scale processes based on carbon capture and valorization. coredata.dc:description: Ni-based catalysts supported on delaminated ITQ-6 zeolite with different Si/Al ratios, 30 and ∞, were tested in the methanation of CO2 and CO. ITQ-6 supports exhibited high surface areas (> 590 m2/g), and the catalysts based on them presented elevated CO2 and CO conversion values, turnover frequencies (TOF), and CH4 selectivity (> 90 %). Comparing the ITQ-6 catalyst and its precursor ferrierite (FER)-based catalyst, H2-chemisorption results confirmed higher metallic dispersion for the former, which resulted in improved H2 uptake and efficient interaction of reaction intermediates via the associative pathway. Combined kinetic studies indicated that their higher available metallic surface contributed to lower apparent activation energies towards CH4 formation, accounting for the higher selectivity values. A 15 wt% Ni-based catalyst supported on ITQ-6 zeolite (Si/Al = 30) exhibited catalytic results (XCO2 = 79 % y SCH4 = 98 %) comparable or even superior to some of the best zeolite-based catalysts reported so far.
